tasks: National Institute of Technology Silchar
Waves and oscillation
Q. 1: The Q value of an underdamped harmonic oscillator of frequency 480 Hz is 80000. Cal-
culate the time in which its amplitude reduces to 1/e of its initial value. How many oscillations
does it make in this time?
Q. 2: A 0.5 kg mass is attached to a spring of spring constant 150 N/m. A driving force
F (t) = 12 cos(ωt ) N is applied to the mass, and the damping coeﬃcient γ is 6 Ns/m. What is
the amplitude of the steady-state motion if ω is equal to half of the natural frequency ω0 of the
system? Find the phase diﬀerence between the forced oscillation and the driving force.
Q. 3: Amplitude of a damped harmonic oscillator decreases by 5% during each oscillatory
cycle. Find the percentage of mechanical energy of the oscillator that is lost in each cycle.
Q. 4: Consider a damped harmonic oscillator of the form ¨x + 2 ˙x + 10x = 0. If x(0) = 4 and
˙x(0) = −4, ﬁnd the solution.
Q. 5: The equation of motion of a damped harmonic oscillator is of the form ¨x+ 2 ˙x+ 10x = 0.
Suggest and explain the nature of damping. Find the frequency of oscillation and the Q value
of the oscillator.
Q. 6: Consider a spring mass system with mass m = 2, spring constant k = 3, and damping
constantc = 1. Is this system underdamped, overdamped or critically damped?
Q. 7: The Q value of a spring loaded with 0 .3 kg is 60. It vibrates with a frequency of 2 Hz.
Calculate the force constant and mechanical resistance.

tasks: Define signals and their role in the context of electrical measurement.
Differentiate between static and dynamic characteristics of measuring instruments.
Identify and categorize different types of electrical instruments used in industry.
Study the operating forces required for the working of indicating instruments.
Compare different types of damping and control systems used in instruments.
Analyze the construction and working principle of Permanent Magnet Moving Coil (PMMC) instruments.
Examine the construction and working principles of Moving Iron (MI) instruments.
Study the principle of Induction type instruments.
Review the design and operation of Electrodynamometer type instruments.
List the applications, advantages, and disadvantages of PMMC, MI, and Induction instruments.
Define calibration and explain its significance in measurement systems.
Distinguish between precision and accuracy with practical examples.
Identify and classify various types of measurement errors.
Research the importance of regular instrument calibration in industrial quality control.
Derive the equation of motion for a galvanometer under different damping conditions.
Analyze the dynamic behavior and response of a galvanometer.
Identify operational constants and Critical Damping Resistance (CDRX).
Calculate relative damping, logarithmic decrement, and sensitivity for galvanometers.
Evaluate the role of galvanometers in modern industrial measurement systems.
Categorize resistance into low, medium, and high measurement ranges.
Master the Kelvin Double Bridge method for low resistance measurement.
Apply the Wheatstone bridge for measuring medium resistance.
Study the operation of a Megger for high resistance and insulation testing.
Explain the direct deflection method for measuring high resistance.
Discuss the significance of resistance measurement in household and industrial safety.
Explain the standardization process for DC and AC potentiometers.
Describe the principle, construction, and working of the Crompton D.C. potentiometer.
Compare Polar and Co-ordinate type potentiometers.
Identify specific industrial use cases for potentiometers.
Analyze the Maxwell Bridge for measuring inductance.
Study Hay's Bridge for the measurement of high-Q coils.
Examine the Schering Bridge for capacitance and dielectric loss measurement.
Apply the De Sauty Bridge for comparing two capacitors.
Evaluate the use of AC bridges for precise parameter measurement in manufacturing.
Study the methods for measurement of electrical power and energy.
Explain the function and application of Current Transformers (CT).
Explain the function and application of Potential Transformers (PT).
Analyze the working of an Electrodynamometer type Wattmeter.
Investigate the operation of an Induction type energy meter.
Study the mechanism of Indicating type Frequency meters.
Review the operation of Electrodynamometer type Power Factor (P.F.) meters.
Assess the role of power, power factor, and frequency in industrial operations.
Identify techniques for measuring temperature and pressure in industrial environments.
Study methods for measuring flow rate and liquid level.
Review the measurement of physical dimensions and chemical composition.
Practice measuring voltage, current, and resistance using multi-meters and specialized ammeters.
Examine methods for measuring mechanical properties like hardness, strain, and torque.
Explain the importance of material characterization in industrial quality control.
Design a basic measuring instrument aimed at minimizing measurement error.
Execute experimental setups to determine and interpret measurement errors.
Analyze industrial components to assess their health condition and standardization.
Design suitable DC bridges for resistance measurement tasks.
Design suitable AC bridges for measuring inductance, capacitance, and frequency.
Acquire and review the textbook by A.K. Sawhney for theoretical foundations.
Consult the Golding and Widdis textbook for advanced measurement principles.
Reference David A. Bell’s text for electronic instrumentation specific details.

tasks: Prep the skin with a hydrating moisturizer and a smoothing primer.
Apply a medium-coverage foundation for an even, natural-looking base.
Sweep a neutral, light-toned eyeshadow across the eyelids.
Define the upper lash line with a thin stroke of black eyeliner.
Apply several coats of lengthening black mascara to the upper lashes.
Dust a soft peach or pink blush onto the apples of the cheeks.
Line and fill the lips with a classic, vibrant red lipstick.
Blow-dry hair using a round brush to add volume at the roots.
Use a large-barrel curling iron to create soft, loose waves throughout the hair.
Style the bangs to sweep across the forehead to one side.
Set the hairstyle with a light-hold hairspray to maintain movement.
Select a white lace top or dress with an intricate floral pattern.
